advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> ARGENTINIAN ADVERT </strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.speccy.org/czarg/" target="_blank">CZARG</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #4</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, APR. 1986</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, NOV. 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ENGLISH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>English advert for the 86A model.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tony Mattson for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LAST +4 SALES, APR. 1986</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE BACK</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Oric opens a full world to you"<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SPANISH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> NASCOM 1 BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (SEPT. 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Arcades games in an armchair"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEWBRAIN BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first Newbrain brochure only offered two models:<br><br> Model AD: with display<br> Model A: without Display <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.oldcomputers.freeserve.co.uk</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (FEBRUARY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"the power of words depends on the way you use them"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>April 1983 <br><br> Advert said <br><br><font color="#666666"> Simple Isn't it?. The COMPAQ portable computer can do what the IBM Personal Computer does. To go.<br><br> It runs all the popular programs written for the IBM. It works for the same printers ans other peripherals. It even accepts the same optional expansion electronics that give it additional capabilities and fonctionality.<br><br> There's really only one big difference. The COMPAQ computer is designed to travel.<br> Carry the COMPAQ computer from office to office. Carry it home on the weekend. Or take it on business trips...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (OCT. 83)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1946...</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an extract of the promotional guide. It says: <br><br> <font color="#666666">1946... Today the TO 7<br> 1946: 30 tons, 160 m²<br> Today: 3.5 Kg, 0.01 m²</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> STUPID PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>An 80's beautiful (!) woman tries to convince us that it's very exciting to work with an Alpha Plus...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> Z-2 1977 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said: Cromemco microcomputers are the fastest and most powerful available. They use the Z80 microprocessor which is widely regarded as the standard of the future. So you're in the technical fore with the Z-2</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 8-PAGE US ADVERT #4</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AN ADVERTISING FOR THE BM JR</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/">Soichiro Oga</a> for this picture !</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>German advert for the Philips Odyssey 200 model.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.dieterkoenig.at/ccc/" target="_blank">Dieter Koening</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> OEMS WANTED</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.coprocessor: playing options (bat size, ball speed, service...)
computer.description:
This pong is one of the many Binatone systems. As its name indicates, it offers 8 games. In order to understand how this system fits into the Binatone pong range, here is simplified list of the systems :
TV Master MK IV TV Master 4 plus 2 TV Master MK 6 TV Master MK 8 TV Master MK 10
Colour TV Game Colour TV Game 4 plus 2 Colour TV Game MK 6 Colour TV Game MK 10
The first serie, TV Master systems, are all black & white pongs, whereas later Colour TV games have colour display. There do not seem to be an equivalent of the TV master MK 8 in the Colour TV Game serie (8 games); mostly because there were no pong-in-a-chip chipset offering 8 colour games available.
Game selection is made through a big rotating knob placed at the centre of the system case. The two detachable analog joysticks can be stored in slide-in compartments located on both sides of the case. The shape of this plastic case is fairly common and many pongs could be found with the same design.
This system seems to be powered by a General Instruments AY-3-8600 chipset(anyone can confirm ?).
computer.keyboard: Two detachable paddles with analog joysticks
computer.name: TV Master MK 8 (model n? 01 / 4823)
